div.script: $(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });
$(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });

span.strong: When will schools reopen?

span.p: On April 6 theIdaho State Board of Education voted unanimously to extend the soft closure of all public schools to the end of this school year. The board also has established the criteria under which school districts may reopen buildings.
At this time, Coeur d'Alene Public Schools is prepared to keep its school buildings closed until summer, while continuing to serve students through remote learning.

span.strong: Will the school year be extended?

span.p: No, we will not extend the 2019-20 school year.

span.strong: How will instruction occur for now?

p.span: Our instructional teams at every grade level have put together a remote learning framework to serve students duringourbuilding closure. Through remote learning, students will be able to finish the school year having met the essential standards and targets most important at their grade level. Remote learning will be challenging, and we dont expect everything to be perfect. This is a major shift in how we provide instruction and support for all students, and we will constantly evaluate how its working and how we can improve the experience for students and families. For more details on how remote elarning will work, see our Back to School Newsletter.

span.strong: Will students be held back if they cannot finish the year because of school closure?

p.span: Students will not be kept at their current grade levels, if that is a concern. We fully expect that catch-up learning for

our students will be required next fall, but we are confident that remote learning this spring will be an effective means of teaching and learning for our teachers and their students in the coming weeks. The more parents can establish routines by having their children read good books, get exercise, take care of themselves, and write every day about topics that interest them, the better their children will navigate these difficult times.

div.script: $(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });
$(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });

span.strong: How will open enrollment work?

p.span: Parents or guardians may apply to enroll their student(s) at the school that they believe will be in the students best interest, even when that school is located outside of their attendance zone.

We will have more guidance and information for elementary families about open enrollment and grandfathering procedures related to attendance zone changes after the Board of Trustees meets April 6 to take final action on our open enrollment and grandfathering policies.

Starting this fall, some families will reside in a new school zone because of the School Boards recent decision to adopt changes in schools boundaries. Some families whose school zone is changing may prefer to keep their student(s) in their current school. That possibility will be determined by the enrollment capacity of the school, as well as the School Boards decisions about open enrollment April 6. If you are a family living in a new school zone, school office personnel will call you to discuss your hopes for your childs school of enrollment.

span.strong: What about kindergarten registration?

p.span: We will kick off Kindergarten registration in April, as usual.
Families will have multiple ways to register their children: online, by phone, or using a paper form. More details will be
. Once we reopen our schools, families also may register in person. The sooner we know who will be joining us next fall, the better we can prepare for our newest class of students!

For Sorensen and Ramsey magnet schools: Kindergarten registration currently is scheduled for April 23: 8-11 a.m. for Sorensen, and 8 a.m.-6 p.m. for Ramsey. This date may be rescheduled if our school closure is extended. We will announce any changes.

span.strong: What about applications to attend a magnet school?

p.span: Parents may submit a magnet school application by the April 10 deadline.
for Sorensen Magnet School of the Arts and Humanities
for Ramsey Magnet School of Science
Print and complete the application, then scan it or take a photo, and email the application and proof of residency (current utility bill) to:
Sorensen:
Ramsey:
You also may mail your completed form and proof of residency to:

p.strong: Sorensen Magnet Schools of the Arts and Sciences

p.span: Attn: Michelle Grebil, Office Manager
310 N. 9th Street
Coeur dAlene, ID 83814
Attn: Theresa Symbal, Registrar
1351 W. Kathleen Ave.
Coeur dAlene, ID 83815

span.strong: Will students still take the ISAT (Idaho Standards Achievement Test)?

p.span: No, the Idaho State Board of Education has canceled the spring ISATs for all students. (Elementary students in grades 3-5 normally take the ISAT
in math, English language arts and science.)

span.strong: Will students still take the Idaho Reading Indicator (IRI)?

p.span: The Idaho State Board of Education has recommended to the governor that the spring IRI requirement for
Kindergarten through third-grade students be waived.
The best ways you can maintain your childs growth as a reader is to:

li.span: Encourage your child to daily read books of interest.
Read stories and books aloud to your child or family.
Read yourself. When adults model reading at home, they have a tremendous impact on their children's reading aptitude and interest.

div.script: $(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });
$(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });

span.strong: What if my student needs a laptop computer at home?

p.span: If you have one or more students in need of a device, let us know by

. We will check out Google Chromebooks to students, starting with seniors and students in dual credit courses, then working down by grade level. This includes students who dont have regular access to a device at home, or homes with multiple students sharing one device. Families will be contacted about when and where to pick up their device at their school.

span.strong: What if we dont have access to the Internet?

p.span: If you do not have Internet service at home,
are offering resources and discounts. You also are invited to let us know about your needs in our

span.strong: We need help logging in

p.span: If your student needs help accessing Clever, Sora or Google Classroom, or the Skyward Student Management System (grades and schedules, communicating with teachers
), we have made this guide to help:

a.span: Parent Guide to Student Usernames and Passwords

span.strong: How do we keep accounts separated?

p.span: With students and parents using the same devices, at times it can be confusing which account is being used. Fortunately, in Google Chrome you can use "Profiles" to keep everything separated and make logging in a breeze. See this guide for detailed directions:

a.span: Using Chrome Profiles to Keep Accounts Separated

span.strong: What if we need help with any of this?

p.span: Have questions of a technical nature? Trouble logging in? You may contact your teacher for guidance on usernames and passwords. You also can contact us at
tech

div.script: $(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });
$(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });

span.p: If you didn't find the answers you were looking for, please let us know. Email us at info@cdaschools.org

div.script: $(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });
$(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });

p.span: Our Special Education staff members are using multiple avenues of providing services to our students with special needs, while keeping the health and safety of our students and staff a priority. This includes everything from paper packets to remote learning to deliver services. We are also placing a strong importance on collaboration and communication between school and home. This situation has proven to be very difficult for many of us to navigate but we are doing our very best to develop innovative solutions. We understand that services may not look the same as they would in the classroom. What is important is that everything we provide as a district is accessible, reasonable, and shows a good faith effort when trying to maintain and grow student skills.
A 504 Plan
ensures that a child who has a disability identified under the law receives accommodations that will ensure access to the learning environment.
As we begin to offer remote learning opportunities after Spring Break,

504 Plan accommodations will be followed as is reasonable under these unusual conditions. Strategies such as providing extended time and shortened assignments would still apply. Remote learning will create a lot of space for students to take advantage of their accommodations. Three-year evaluations can wait until school buildings reopen. Expired 504s will still be valid during this time. If you have any concerns, please reach out to your child's teacher or school counselor.

div.script: $(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });
$(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });

span.strong: How will open enrollment work?

p.span: Parents or guardians may apply to enroll their student(s) at the school that they believe will be in the students best interest, even when that school is located outside of their attendance zone. The new window for Secondary Open Enrollment will be April 13-30. Applications will be online and accessible through the

. Paper copies of the Open Enrollment forms are available upon request by calling the Department of Secondary Education at (208) 664-8241 ext. 10003. Completed paper forms can be mailed to the District Office, 1400 N. Northwood Center Court, Coeur dAlene, ID 83814.

span.strong: How will grades work for middle school students?

p.span: Teachers will provide feedback and formative assessment, but not grades, during the school closure.

span.strong: Will high school students still be able to earn credits?

p.span: Yes, high school students will earn credit for the second semester classes they pass. More information about how grading will work for the semester will be available soon. Dual Credit and Idaho Digital Learning Academy courses will be provided online. Grading for these courses is determined by the individual entity.

span.strong: What about senior projects?

p.span: All senior project requirements for the 2nd semester are now considered complete. Seniors will receive a pass grade and credit for their senior project.
The Idaho State Board of Education has waived the senior project graduation requirement for the class of 2020. High schools may offer ways to celebrate seniors who completed their projects.

span.strong: Will my senior still graduate?

p.span: Seniors will still graduate if they are on track to graduate and receive a passing grade for the courses taken in the second semester. On track to graduate means between the students scheduled classes this spring (including any scheduled credit recovery courses) and the students accumulated credits as of the end of first semester, the student would meet the credit requirements for graduation. The Civics Test is still a graduation requirement per state law. Most seniors have already passed this assessment. The district will communicate and work with seniors who still need to pass this assessment.

span.strong: How will this affect scholarship requirements and NCAA student-athlete eligibility?

p.span: Organizations offering scholarships may announce changes in eligibility requirements in response to school closings and adjustments being made for the remainder of this school year. Visit the organizations website to learn more. You also may check with the school counseling office for updates. W
e are working to make sure students are not penalized.

span.strong: Will there be high school commencement ceremonies for graduating seniors?

p.span: We certainly hope so. We do not know yet how commencement might be affected by the coronavirus pandemic and related restrictions on gatherings. We will know more in the coming weeks and will keep our seniors and families informed of potential changes. However, we are currently exploring alternatives if restrictions are still in place.

span.strong: Will senior proms still happen?

span.p: We are continually evaluating whether it will be possible to hold proms this spring. Both have been postponed at this point, and we will make a final decision in early May.
The Coeur dAlene High School Senior Ball tentatively is scheduled for May 23.
The Lake City High School Senior Ball tentatively is scheduled for May 30.

span.strong: Will students still take the ISAT (Idaho Standards Achievement Test)?

p.span: No, the Idaho State Board of Education has canceled the spring ISATs for all students. (Students in grades
6-8 and 10 normally
take the ISAT
in math, English language arts and science.)

span.strong: Do seniors still need to take the SAT to graduate?

p.span: If seniors had not yet taken a college-entrance exam, the Idaho State Board of Education has waived this requirement for this school year.

span.strong: Will juniors still take the SAT?

span.p: Current juniors will still need to take a college-entrance exam in order to graduate.The Idaho Department of Education has canceled the SAT School Day scheduled for April 28. The state isworking with the College Board on options for juniors to take the SAT at a later date.

span.strong: What about the ACT college admissions exam?

p.span: has rescheduled its April 4 national test date to June 13 across the U.S. All students registered for the April 4 test date will receive an email from ACT informing them of the postponement and instructions for free rescheduling to June 13 or a future national test date.

span.strong: Will students in AP (Advanced Placement) classes take their May exams?

p.span: Yes, students who have signed up will still be able to take their AP exams. The College Board is providing the exam online. The format and content of the test has changed in response to school closures across the nation. Information can be found on

span.strong: Will seniors still need to pass the Civics Assessment for graduation?

p.span: The Idaho State Board of Education has recommended to the governor that this graduation
be waived for seniors.

span.strong: More details on state assessments

p.span: For more infomation about state assessments, read our newsletter here.

span.strong: Arespring sports and activities be canceled?

p.span: Yes. On April 17, the Idaho High School Activities Association

Board of Directors announced that all spring sport and activity seasons and all state tournaments are cancelled. This decision was based on guidelines established by Gov. Brad Little, the Idaho State Board of Education, as well as feedback from schools and districts throughout the state.

span.strong: What about Drivers Education?

p.span: Students in the current section will be given the opportunity to finish when school resumes or receive a refund. Letters will be sent out to the parents of current students explaining their options and next steps. All future classes are on hold until further notice.

div.script: $(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });
$(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });

span.strong: When and where are Grab-N-Go meals available?

p.span: Free Grab-N-Go meals from Coeur dAlene Public Schools are available for children ages 1-18 Monday through Friday during the school closure. We are handing out a breakfast bag and a lunch bag together each day from school buses at 12 locations in our district. Pickup times are 11 a.m. or 11:45 a.m., depending on location. For a schedule and other details,

span.strong: What type of child care is available at this time?

p.span: Emergency K-5 child care is available at Ramsey Magnet School and Skyway Elementary School. This is for Coeur dAlene School District students whose parents or guardians work in healthcare or emergency services. THERE IS NO COST FOR THIS SERVICE. The hours are 6:45 a.m. to 6 p.m. weekdays.
to enroll a student in our Emergency K-5 Child Care if you work in a hospital or other healthcare facility, or if you work in law enforcement or emergency services.

Because of the need to focus our staff resources on providing the emergency child care during the coronavirus pandemic, we have suspended our regular School PLUS child care program until further notice. For those who have prepaid for School PLUS, a credit will be applied to your account for all days the program remains closed. If you have questions for us, please let us know. You may email us at
schoolplus@cdaschools.org

button.aria-label: Scroll to the top of the page.

div.span: The Coeur dAlene School District complies with all applicable laws and does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age (40 or older), genetic information, veteran status or disability in any educational programs or activities receiving federal financial assistance or in employment practices. The District provides equal access to the Boy Scouts and other designated youth groups. Inquiries regarding compliance with this nondiscrimination policy may be directed to the Section 504 Program Coordinator or Director of Human Resources at the District Office, 1400 N. Northwood Center Ct., Coeur dAlene, Idaho 83814, (208) 664-8241.
